sen.j: 石塔寺（いしどうじ）は、滋賀県東近江市にある天台宗の寺院。
sen.e: Ishido-ji Temple is the Tendai sect temple located at Higashiomi City, Shiga Prefecture.
Ishido-ji Temple is a Tendai sect temple located in Higashiomi City, Shiga Prefecture.
Ishido-ji Temple is a Tendai sect temple located in Higashiomi City, Shiga Prefecture.

sen.j: 山号は阿育王山（あしょかおうざん）、本尊は聖観音（秘仏）。
sen.e: Sango (title given to Buddhist temple) is Aikuo-zan Mountain, and honzon (principle image of Buddha) is Sho Kannon (Buddhist image normally withheld from public view).
Its sango (title given to a Buddhist temple) is Ashokao-zan Mountain, and its honzon (principle image of Buddha) is Sho Kannon (Buddhist image normally withheld from public view).
sen.cmt: 冠詞の修正、「阿育王山（あしょかおうざん）」という原文の読みを無視した訳になっているので修正
sen.e: Its sango (title given to a Buddhist temple) is Ashokao-zan Mountain, and its honzon (principle image of Buddha) is Sho Kannon (Buddhist image normally withheld from public view).

sen.j: 「石塔寺」の名のとおり、境内には、アショーカ王アショーカ王の柱と呼ばれる石造三重塔を中心に、数万基の石塔や石仏が並ぶ。
sen.e: Just as the name 'Ishido-ji' (stone pagoda temple), in the precincts there are tens of thousands of pagodas, or stone Buddhist images centered around the three-storied stone pagoda called the pillars of King Ashoka.
sen.cmt: 原文、「アショーカ王アショーカ王の柱」とありますが、アショーカ王が二度記載されているのは間違いではないかと思います。
sen.e: Just as the name 'Ishido-ji' (stone pagoda temple) shows, there are tens of thousands of pagodas and stone Buddhist images around the three-storied stone pagoda called the pillars of King Ashoka in the precincts.
sen.cmt: わかりにくいので語順を変更
sen.e: Just as the name 'Ishido-ji' (stone pagoda temple) shows, there are tens of thousands of pagodas and stone Buddhist images around the three-storied stone pagoda called the pillars of King Ashoka in the precincts.

sen.j: 毎年8月末には、「石塔フェスティバル（石塔寺万燈祭）」が開かれ、石塔と石仏に献灯が行われる。
sen.e: Every year at the end of August, the 'Stone Pagoda Festival' (Ishido-ji Manto (lantern) Festival) takes place, where stone pagodas and stone Buddhist images are lit up with votive lanterns.
At the end of August, 'Stone Pagoda Festival' (Ishido-ji Manto [lantern] Festival) takes place every year, and stone pagodas and stone Buddhist images are lit up with votive lanterns.
sen.cmt: 「every year」の位置を変更、冠詞の修正。
sen.e: At the end of August, 'Stone Pagoda Festival' (Ishido-ji Manto [lantern] Festival) takes place every year, and stone pagodas and stone Buddhist images are lit up with votive lanterns.

sen.j: 近江西国三十三箇所観音霊場第二十二番札所。
sen.e: The 22nd temple of 33 Omi Saigoku Kannon Pilgrimage.
This is the 22nd temple of 33 Omi Saigoku Kannon Pilgrimage.
This is the 22nd temple of 33 Omi Saigoku Kannon Pilgrimage.

sen.j: 石塔寺は、聖徳太子創建の伝承をもつ寺院である。
sen.e: Ishido-ji is a Buddhist temple with the tradition of having founded by Prince Shotoku.
Ishido-ji Temple is a Buddhist temple which is said to have been founded by Prince Shotoku.
sen.cmt: Templeの追加、「伝承をもつ」という箇所の表現の変更
sen.e: Ishido-ji Temple is a Buddhist temple which is said to have been founded by Prince Shotoku.

sen.j: 伝承によれば、聖徳太子は近江に48か寺を建立し、石塔寺は48番目の満願の寺院で、本願成就寺と称したという。
sen.e: According to the tradition, Prince Shotoku erected 48 temples in Omi, and Ishido-ji was the 48th temple with the fulfillment of a vow, and was called Hongan Joju-ji Temple.

According to that tradition, Prince Shotoku erected 48 temples in Omi Province, and Ishido-ji Temple was the 48th temple with the fulfillment of a vow, and it was called Hongan (which literally means main wish) Joju-ji Temple.
sen.cmt: OmiにProvinceを追加、Templeという語の追加、「本願」という語の意味の説明を追加（なぜそう呼ばれるか、ローマ字表記だけではわからないため）
sen.e: According to that tradition, Prince Shotoku erected 48 temples in Omi Province, and Ishido-ji Temple was the 48th temple with the fulfillment of a vow, and it was called Hongan (which literally means main wish) Joju-ji Temple.

sen.j: 聖徳太子創建との伝承をそのまま史実と受け取ることはできない。
sen.e: The tradition which tells of the foundation by Prince Shotoku cannot be taken in as a historical fact as it is.
The tradition which tells Prince Shotoku built this temple cannot be accepted as a historical fact.
sen.cmt: 「聖徳太子創建」の箇所の表現を訂正、taken in をacceptedと変更。
sen.e: The tradition which tells Prince Shotoku built this temple cannot be accepted as a historical fact.

sen.j: しかし、石塔寺がある滋賀県湖東地区には他にも西国三十三箇所札所寺院の長命寺（近江八幡市）、百済寺（ひゃくさいじ、東近江市）など、聖徳太子創建伝承をもつ寺院が多く、この地が早くから仏教文化の栄えた土地であるとともに、聖徳太子とも何らかのつながりのあったことを思わせる。
sen.e: However, in the Koto region Shiga Prefecture where Ishido-ji Temple is located, there are many other temples with the tradition which tells of the foundation by Prince Shotoku such as Chomei-ji Temple (Omihachiman City), Hyakusai-ji Temple (Higashiomi City) of 33 Saigoku Kannon Pilgrimage which makes it seem that this was the region in which the Buddhist culture prospered from early times, and had some sort of connection with the Prince Shotoku.

However, in the Koto region in Shiga Prefecture, where Ishido-ji Temple is, there are many other temples with a legendary story of Prince Shotoku's foundation such as Chomei-ji Temple (Omihachiman City), which is one of 33 Saigoku Kannon Pilgrimages, and Hyakusai-ji Temple (Higashiomi City), and this area may be a region in which the Buddhist culture prospered from early times, with some sort of connection with Prince Shotoku.

However, in the Koto region in Shiga Prefecture, where Ishido-ji Temple is, there are many other temples with a legendary story of Prince Shotoku's foundation such as Chomei-ji Temple (Omihachiman City), which is one of 33 Saigoku Kannon Pilgrimages, and Hyakusai-ji Temple (Higashiomi City), and this area may be a region in which the Buddhist culture prospered from early times, with some sort of connection with Prince Shotoku.

sen.j: 石塔寺境内にある数万基の石塔群の中で、ひときわ高くそびえる三重石塔については、次のような伝承がある。
sen.e: The following tradition is told about the three-storied pagoda that stands particularly higher than the other tens of thousands of pagodas in the precincts of Ishido-ji Temple.
People still have the following tradition about the highest three-storied pagoda among tens of thousands of pagodas in the precincts of Ishido-ji Temple.
People still have the following tradition about the highest three-storied pagoda among tens of thousands of pagodas in the precincts of Ishido-ji Temple.

sen.j: 平安時代の長保3年（1003年）に唐に留学した比叡山の僧・寂照法師は、五台山 (中国)に滞在中、五台山の僧から、「昔インドの阿育王が仏教隆盛を願って三千世界に撒布した8万4千基の仏舎利塔のうち、2基が日本に飛来しており、1基は琵琶湖の湖中に沈み、1基は近江国渡来山（わたらいやま）の土中にある」と聞いた。
sen.e: In 1003, during the Heian period, the monk Jakusho Hoshi of Mt. Hiei-zan who studied abroad in Tang, while staying in Mt. Wutai Shan (China), heard a story from the monk in Mt. Wutai Shan that 'a long time ago, Ashoka the Great of India prayed for the prosperity of Buddhism and distributed 84,000 stupa to the whole world and 2 made their way to Japan of which 1 sunk underneath the Lake Biwa, and 1 is under the ground of Mt. Watarai-yama Omi Province'.

In 1003, during the Heian period, Jakusho Hoshi, a monk from Mt. Hiei-zan who studied abroad in Tang, heard the following story from a monk in Mt. Wutai Shan while he stayed in Mt. Wutai Shan (China); a long time ago, Ashoka the Great of India prayed for the prosperity of Buddhism and distributed 84,000 stupa to the whole world, and two of them are in Japan, but one is under the Lake Biwa while the other is under the ground of Mt. Watarai-yama in Omi Province.

In 1003, during the Heian period, Jakusho Hoshi, a monk from Mt. Hiei-zan who studied abroad in Tang, heard the following story from a monk in Mt. Wutai Shan while he stayed in Mt. Wutai Shan (China); a long time ago, Ashoka the Great of India prayed for the prosperity of Buddhism and distributed 84,000 stupa to the whole world, and two of them are in Japan, but one is under the Lake Biwa while the other is under the ground of Mt. Watarai-yama in Omi Province.

sen.j: 寂照は日本に手紙を送ってこのことを知らせた。
sen.e: Jakusho wrote a letter to Japan to deliver the news.
Jakusho wrote a letter to Japan to deliver the news.
Jakusho wrote a letter to Japan to deliver the news.

sen.j: 3年後の寛弘3年（1006年）、播州明石（兵庫県明石市）の僧・義観僧都がこの手紙を入手し、一条天皇に上奏した。
sen.e: 3 years later in 1006, the monk Gikan Sozu of Banshu Akashi (Akashi City, Hyogo Prefecture) received this letter and delivered it to Emperor Ichijo.
Three years later after that, in 1006, the monk Gikan Sozu of Banshu Akashi (Akashi City, Hyogo Prefecture) obtained this letter and delivered it to Emperor Ichijo.
Three years later after that, in 1006, the monk Gikan Sozu of Banshu Akashi (Akashi City, Hyogo Prefecture) obtained this letter and delivered it to Emperor Ichijo.

sen.j: そして、一条天皇の勅命により、塔の探索を行ったところ、武士の野谷光盛なる者が、石塔寺の裏山に大きな塚を発見した。
sen.e: Then, due to the imperial order from Emperor Ichijo, the search of the pagoda was conducted, and the samurai, NODANI no Mitsumori found a big mound in the hill at the back of Ishido-ji Temple.
Accordingly, the search of the pagoda was conducted by an imperial order from Emperor Ichijo, and a samurai called NODANI no Mitsumori found a big mound in the hill at the back of Ishido-ji Temple.
sen.cmt: Then をAccordinlyに変更、文章前半の語順を変更、冠詞の修正
sen.e: Accordingly, the search of the pagoda was conducted by an imperial order from Emperor Ichijo, and a samurai called NODANI no Mitsumori found a big mound in the hill at the back of Ishido-ji Temple.

sen.j: 野谷光盛と天皇の勅使平恒昌が掘ってみたところ、阿育王塔が出土した。
sen.e: When NODANI no Mitsumori and the imperial messenger for the Emperor, TAIRA no Tsunemasa dug the ground, pagoda of Ashoka the Great was excavated.
When NODANI no Mitsumori and TAIRA no Tsunemasa, an imperial messenger of the Emperor, dug the ground, they found a pagoda of Ashoka the Great.
When NODANI no Mitsumori and TAIRA no Tsunemasa, an imperial messenger of the Emperor, dug the ground, they found a pagoda of Ashoka the Great.

sen.j: 一条天皇は大変喜び、七堂伽藍を新たに建立し、寺号を阿育王山石塔寺と改号した。
sen.e: Emperor Ichijo was so pleased that he erected a new Shichidogaran (seven major structures in a temple compound) and changed the name of the temple title to Aikuo-zan Ishido-ji Temple.
Emperor Ichijo was so pleased that he erected a new Shichidogaran (seven major structures in a temple compound) and changed the name of the temple title to Aikuo-zan Ishido-ji Temple.
Emperor Ichijo was so pleased that he erected a new Shichidogaran (seven major structures in a temple compound) and changed the name of the temple title to Aikuo-zan Ishido-ji Temple.

sen.j: 寺は一条天皇の勅願寺となり、隆盛を極め、八十余坊の大伽藍を築いたという。
sen.e: The temple became the chokugan-ji (temple built at the order of the emperor) of Emperor Ichijo, and he thoroughly tried to conduct prosperity, and built a large Buddhist temple of 八十余坊.
The temple became a chokugan-ji (temple built by order of the emperor) of Emperor Ichijo, and he thoroughly tried to conduct prosperity, and built a large Buddhist temple with more than 80 rooms.
sen.cmt: 「八十余坊」が未翻訳。坊は単位。固有名詞ではない。
sen.e: The temple became a chokugan-ji (temple built by order of the emperor) of Emperor Ichijo, and he thoroughly tried to conduct prosperity, and built a large Buddhist temple with more than 80 rooms.

sen.j: 以上の伝承のうち、「インドの阿育王」云々が後世の仮託であることは言うまでもなく、件の石塔は、実際には奈良時代前期（7世紀）頃に、朝鮮半島系の渡来人によって建立されたとみるのが通説である。
sen.e: It goes without saying that of all the traditions, the tale of 'Ashoka the Great of India' was the pretext of the posterity, and the actual accepted theory was that this pagoda was erected by the settlers from Chosun peninsula around the beginning of Nara period (7th century).

Needless to say, the tale of 'Ashoka the Great of India' among all those legendary stories is a pretext added by the posterity, and a generally-accepted theory is that this pagoda was erected by settlers from Chosun Peninsula around the beginning of the Nara period (the seventh century).

Needless to say, the tale of 'Ashoka the Great of India' among all those legendary stories is a pretext added by the posterity, and a generally-accepted theory is that this pagoda was erected by settlers from Chosun Peninsula around the beginning of the Nara period (the seventh century).

sen.j: この石塔は、日本各地にある中世以前の石塔とは全く異なった様式をもつものであり、朝鮮半島の古代の石造物に類似している。
sen.e: This pagoda has a completely different pattern than of other pagodas that can be seen in many parts of Japan from before medieval times, and it is similar to stone structural objects from ancient Chosun peninsula.

This pagoda has a completely different style from other pagodas built in or before the middle ages which are seen in many regions in Japan, and it is similar to ancient stone structural objects in Chosun Peninsula.

This pagoda has a completely different style from other pagodas built in or before the middle ages which are seen in many regions in Japan, and it is similar to ancient stone structural objects in Chosun Peninsula.

sen.j: 湖東地区が渡来人と関係の深い土地であることは、『日本書紀』に天智天皇8年（669年）、百済（当時すでに滅亡していた）からの渡来人700名余を近江国蒲生野（滋賀県蒲生郡あたり）へ移住させた旨の記述があることからも裏付けられている。
sen.e: It can be said that Koto is a region which has close relations with the settlers, by the statement in "Nihon Shoki" (the Chronicle of Japan) which mentions in 669, about 700 settlers had immigrated from Kudara (Baekje, Paekche) (already fallen back then) to Gamafuno Omi Province (around Gamafuno Shiga Prefecture), and it can be viewed that the three-storied pagoda of Ishido-ji Temple was erected by the settlers of Kudara.

Koto is a region which has close relations with the settlers, and this is backed up by some statements in "Nihon Shoki" (the Chronicle of Japan) such as a story that in 669, about 700 settlers immigrated from Baekje (already fallen back then) to Gamafuno, Omi Province (around Gamafuno, Shiga Prefecture).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処 としました。全体を修正しました。
sen.e: Koto is a region which has close relations with the settlers, and this is backed up by some statements in "Nihon Shoki" (the Chronicle of Japan) such as a story that in 669, about 700 settlers immigrated from Baekje (already fallen back then) to Gamafuno, Omi Province (around Gamafuno, Shiga Prefecture).

sen.j: 石塔寺の三重石塔も百済系の渡来人によって建立されたものであるとの見方が一般的である。
sen.e: Additionally, it is generally thought that the three-storied pagoda of Ishido-ji Temple was erected by the settlers of Kudara.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処 としました。
sen.e: Additionally, it is generally thought that the three-storied pagoda of Ishido-ji Temple was erected by the settlers of Kudara.

sen.j: 鎌倉時代には、三重石塔（伝・阿育王塔）の周りの境内に、五輪塔や石仏が多数奉納された。
sen.e: In the Kamakura period, many gorinto (a gravestone composed of five pieces piled up one upon another) and stone Buddhist image were dedicated to the precincts around the three-storied pagoda (called Aikuo pagoda).

In the Kamakura period, many gorinto (a gravestone composed of five pieces piled up one upon another) and stone Buddhist images were dedicated to the three-storied pagoda (called Aikuo pagoda) in the precincts.
sen.cmt: imageをimagesに変更、the precinctsの位置を変えました。
sen.e: In the Kamakura period, many gorinto (a gravestone composed of five pieces piled up one upon another) and stone Buddhist images were dedicated to the three-storied pagoda (called Aikuo pagoda) in the precincts.

sen.j: 安土桃山時代、織田信長の焼き討ちにより、七堂伽藍、木造建築物、寺宝が全て焼失し、寺は荒廃した。
sen.e: In the Azuchi Momoyama period, due to the fire set by Nobunaga ODA, all of Shichidogaran, wooden buildings, temple's treasures were destroyed in the fire, and the temple was ruined.
In the Azuchi Momoyama period, due to the fire set by Nobunaga ODA, all of Shichidogaran, wooden buildings, the temple's treasures were destroyed in the fire, and the temple was ruined.
In the Azuchi Momoyama period, due to the fire set by Nobunaga ODA, all of Shichidogaran, wooden buildings, the temple's treasures were destroyed in the fire, and the temple was ruined.

sen.j: その後、江戸時代初期、天海が弟子の行賢に指示し、一部復興されている。
sen.e: Then in the beginning of the Edo period, Tenkai ordered his pupil Gyoken, and it was partially restored.
After that, in the beginning of the Edo period, the temple was partially restored because Tenkai told his pupil Gyoken to do so.
sen.cmt: ThenをAfter thatに変更、語順を変更
sen.e: After that, in the beginning of the Edo period, the temple was partially restored because Tenkai told his pupil Gyoken to do so.

sen.j: 重要文化財
sen.e: Important cultural property
Important Cultural Property
Important Cultural Property

sen.j: 石造三重塔（伝・阿育王塔） - 奈良時代前期建立。
sen.e: Three-storied stone pagoda (called Aikuo pagoda) - Erected in the early Nara period.
Three-storied stone pagoda (called Ashurao pagoda) - Erected in the early Nara period.
Three-storied stone pagoda (called Ashurao pagoda) - Erected in the early Nara period.

sen.j: 石造層塔としては日本最古であり、石造三重塔としては日本最大。
sen.e: It is Japan's oldest stone pagoda, and the biggest three-stone pagoda.
This is Japan's oldest stone pagoda, and this is the biggest three-stone pagoda in Japan.
sen.cmt: ItをThisに変更、後半の節に主語とin Japanを追加
sen.e: This is Japan's oldest stone pagoda, and this is the biggest three-stone pagoda in Japan.

sen.j: 高さ7.6ｍ。
sen.e: Height 7.6m.
Height 7.6m.
Height 7.6m.

sen.j: 石材は花崗岩。
sen.e: Stone (building stone) is granite.
This is made of granite.
This is made of granite.

sen.j: 石造宝塔 - 正安4年（1302年）の建立。
sen.e: Stone hoto-pagoda - Erected in 1302.
Stone hoto-pagoda - Erected in 1302.
Stone hoto-pagoda - Erected in 1302.

sen.j: 「宝塔」は、円筒形の塔身に宝形造（四角錐形）の屋根を付した形式の塔を指す。
sen.e: Hoto' (treasure tower) is a cylindrical type of pagoda and hogyo-zukuri style roof (all the roof ridges gathering at the center) (quadrilateral structure).
The term "Hoto" (treasure tower) refers to a cylindrical type of pagoda with a hogyo-zukuri style roof (all the roof ridges gathering at the center) in quadrilateral structure.
sen.cmt: 冒頭にThe termを追加し、用語の説明がわかるようダブルクオーテーションを追加しました。
sen.e: The term 'Hoto' (treasure tower) refers to a cylindrical type of pagoda with a hogyo-zukuri style roof (all the roof ridges gathering at the center) in quadrilateral structure.

sen.j: 石造五輪塔（2基） - それぞれ嘉元2年（1304年）および貞和5年（1349年）の建立。
sen.e: Stone gorinto (2 tower) - Each erected in 1304 and 1349.
Two stone gorinto - Erected in 1304 and 1349 respectively.
sen.cmt: 2はTwoに訂正、「それぞれ」はrespectivelyに変更
sen.e: Two stone gorinto - Erected in 1304 and 1349 respectively.

sen.j: JR琵琶湖線 近江八幡駅下車 近江バス（日野行き） 桜川駅バス停下車 湖国バス（中之郷行き）乗り換え 石塔口バス停下車 徒歩15分
sen.e: Take the JR Biwako line to Omihachiman, then take Omi Bus (bound for Hino) to Sakuragawa-eki bus stop, transfer to Kokoku Bus, get off at Ishitoguchi Bus stop and walk for 15 minutes.
Take the JR Biwako line to Omihachiman, and then take Omi Bus (bound for Hino) transferring to Kokoku Bus at Sakuragawa-eki, and get off the bus at Ishitoguchi followed by 15-minute walk.
